p.hi: SOME OBSERVATIONS BEARING ON THE CONTROL OF MALARIA

div1.p:
By
P. M. ASHBURN,
Major, Medical Corps, U. S. A.,
General Inspector, Health Department,
Panama Canal.

When I came to the Isthmus I was familiar with the excel-
lent work done by Mr. Le Prince and his assistants in determining the
origin of the great flights of Anopheles at Gatun in 1912 and 1913, at
which time it was clearly and definitely shown that the flight of
Anopheles albimanus and Anopheles tarsimaculata might be as long as
a mile and a quarter, and that across a fairly stiff breeze.

At the same time I knew that great good had been accom-
plished in diminishing malaria here and in many parts of the world
without making allowances for flights nearly so long as that demon-
strated at Gatun, most workers having accomplished their results
without going more than a few hundred yards from houses.

It was not long until I began to learn from conversations
with Sanitary Inspectors that places which a few years ago, when
populated, were great hot beds of malaria and great breeding places
for Anopheles albimanus, now, since their depopulation, have very
few or no Anopheles. Among places of this character Mr. Chidester
told me of an area back of the new waterworks at Miraflores, and
of another at Cocoli, and Mr. Trask told me of Ancon village in
Culebra district. Then too, in one or two instances where we were
finding a good many anopheles which were supposed to have come from
2
considerable distances, the situations were found controllable by in-
tensive effort expended close at hand. At Pedro Miguel, for instance,
a considerable mosquito catch in two particular buildings was attri-
buted by experienced inspectors to breeding places a thousand yards
distant; where larvae were found. Yet by decreasing, instead of in-
creasing, the extent of our work, the situation was controlled.

After a time hydraulic fills at Mindi Island (Cristobal),
and near Ancon and the San Miguel district of Panama were found to be
giving rise to great Anopheles breeding, probably similar to, though,
less extensive than, that at Gatun in 1912-13. But, unlike that
Gatun fill, these, while producing great numbers of mosquitoes, did
not give rise to flights of any such length. In fact Ancon, though
much less than a mile from the San Miguel fill, was practically un-
affected by it. The reason for this appeared plain. There was
food nearer at hand.

This led to the thought of interposing an animal barrier
between extensive anopheles breeding places and human habitations,
but little consideration was necessary to recall places where the
animals were present but did not serve as barriers, among such places
being the San Miguel fill, near which two dairies are located. On
the other hand, it was known that extensive Anopheles breeding oc-
curred in places frequented by cattle and almost unvisited by persons.

At about the same time I saw a report of Strickland's inter-
esting observation that the rat flea of England (C. fasciata) will
3
bite man as readily as it will bite a rat, but that it will not co-
pulate until after a feed of rat-blood.

From the above facts the following hypothesis was evolved.
I state it in three parts.

A. Parasitism - Yellow fever is transmitted by Aedes calopus
(Stegomyia fasciata) and malaria by certain anophelines because
through the ages those particular mosquitoes have been so closely
associated with man that an adaptation of mosquito, disease germ and
man has occurred. It has occurred because those particular mosqui-
toes want human blood to the exclusion of other varieties, and it is
possible that they cannot perpetuate their species except when they
get human blood.

(Dr. Darling has undertaken work that should tend to prove or
disprove this, but it has thus far been defeated by the difficulty
of rearing Anopheles on any diet. Work will be done with Stegomyia,
though that will not directly prove anything in regard to malaria.)
Stegomyia will bite
genuine pigs & breed
thereafter - P.M.A.

B. Long flights - In consequence of this yearning for a par-
ticular kind of blood, Anopheles albimanus and Anopheles tarsimaculata,
and probably other malaria-bearing Anopheles and possibly Stegomyia,
will make great flights to obtain it, as did Anopheles Albimanus and
Anopheles tarsimaculata at Gatun, provided that it cannot be obtained
nearer at hand. If it be at hand they will take it and not make the
long flights. Having made a very long flight and obtained a full
feed of blood, the female would stand a relatively poor chance of
4
getting back to the place where she was bred, because of difficulty
of her flight and her consequent greater exposure to natural enemies.
The tendency therefore would be for such long flights to be self
limited, unless a few persons living near the breeding place fur-
nished enough blood to keep up the breeding but not enough to sup-
ply all of the mosquitoes bred. Under special conditions a few
breeding mosquitoes might produce a great progeny because, owing to
the breeding places being newly made and artificial, the natural
enemies of the mosquitoes have not yet come into action in them and,
for a time, practically all eggs laid result in full grown mosqui-
toes. This was true, I think, at Gatun, and it may be an important
factor in all of those severe outbreaks of malaria that arise on new
railway work and other extensive work in the tropics.

C. Anopheles breeding far from man not Malaria Carriers - If
malaria carrying Anopheles normally breed only close to man, those
Anopheles found breeding far from habitations and from places of com-
mon human resort should not be malaria carriers.

I have the excellent authority of Dr. Darling for stating that
A. apicimaculata is not a carrier of malaria.

The following places that formerly produced large numbers
of A. albimanus have recently been carefully searched by the inspectors
named and are reported to be producing none, the change being attribu-
ted to the fact that the places are uninhabited and that no work is
going on in the neighborhood, the conditions, in other respects, being
most favorable to breeding:

An interesting bit of evidence was afforded by the Cardenas River.
Anopheles breeding was reported from there in September and I had lar-
vae sent in for identification about October 1st. Dr. Darling found
them to be A. Albimanus. There were no habitations within a half mile
of the place but a large gang of negroes had been working near there,
laying the new water main. They finished there at about the time the
larvae were identified and I instructed the Sanitary Inspectors to leave
the place untreated and gather more larvae after November 1st. Mr.
Chidester reports that he has carefully searched the neighborhood several
times since that date and has been unable to find any larvae whatever.

I have tried to get the record of a newly established town in
order to note in it the rise of Anopheles and Mmalaria. The only new
town made for which the data are available is the present La Boca,
6
where both mosquitoes and malaria have been kept at negligible figures.
partly because of the town's good natural features and the good planning
and construction of it, partly by work.

The nearest approach to what I sought was the contractor's camp
at Cano Saddle. That camp was established November 26, 1913, at an un-
inhabited place. The nearest and only house about was a quarter of a
mile away. Hand catching of mosquitoes was begun early and the Anopheles
catch was as follows:

It will be noted that the catch was lowest at the beginning, a time
when seasonal conditions favored breeding, that after the first two
or three weeks the mosquitoes increased rapidly up to the 21st of
March, after which a decline in numbers began. This decline may
7
have been due in part to the advance of the dry season, in part
to the establishment of a balance between mosquitoes and their
natural enemies. No anti-mosquito work was done, except the
catching of adults. Now as to malaria there: the figures are
unduly favorable and are possibly misleading because the per-
sonnel changed frequently and there is no doubt that men con-
tracted malaria there whose cases do not show on the reports.
Only those sent away to hospital do show. That malaria carriers
were present from the beginning I have no doubt, as I think it
would be almost impossible to pick at random 100 or more laborers
without finding some. However, I have no examinations of the men
there at that time to support my belief.

The first case of malaria sent to hospital was sent in
the week ending February 7th, four cases were sent in March, five
in April, and one in the first week of May, after which the camp
closed.

On December 19, 1913, Dr. M. E. Connor inspected the place
and predicted malaria, but did not report its presence. On
February 9, 1914, Dr. Farmer inspected the camp and reported the
presence of two cases of fever. Dr. H. C. Clark examined blood
specimens taken from 62 men of the camp on March 16th and found
malaria in 6, a rate of 9.7 percent. He examined blood drawn from
30 other individuals on March 31st and found malaria in 6, - 20 per-
cent. He examined 2 other bloods on April 4th and found malaria
8
in both. We are justified in stating that at Caño Saddle, a
place characterized by Dr. Connor as highly favorable to malaria,
Anopheles did not greatly abound until after the laborers had
been there for three weeks or more, and malaria made no headway
until after two months. It is probable that that uninhabited
place was also uninhabited by mosquitoes capable of bearing
malaria until the workmen took them there and created conditions
particularly favorable for their breeding.

Let us, in view of what has been said, turn back to a
further consideration of the big Gatun flight, and see if the
facts available explain them. Mr. J. A. Corrigan, who has been
Sanitary Inspector at Gatun for years, informs me that when Fill
No. 1, just north of the lighthouse, and Fill No. 2, on the Colon-
Gatun road, were made, they gave rise to no great and extended
flights, but did cause a local increase of mosquitoes, the former
causing the increase in the barracks nearest it and the latter in
the houses in Stillson's addition. On the other hand, Fill No. 3,
across the canal and over a mile away, caused great flights to
Gatun, which flights continued for months. I would call atten-
tion to the fact that both 1 and 2 were close and convenient to
large negro populations and long flights were unnecessary. With
Fill No. 3 the case was different. There a large area, one mile
by one-half mile, mostly fresh water swamp, was being filled.
The fill was of mud and salt water. The mixture of fresh and
9
salt water is most favorable to A. albimanus and A. tarsimaculata,
while it is probably unfavorable or fatal to the natural enemies of
the mosquitoes that normally dwell in fresh water, as it certainly
is to the ordinary vegetation of the swamp. In the vicinity of
this fill and serving as food supply for a moderate number of mos-
quitoes were: (1) Certain dredge pipe workers, probably a few dozen,
(2) the inhabitants of FormeTorna Sabalo, probably 100, and (3) the in-
habitants of Boracho, probably 20. Soon the whole fill area was
breeding mosquitoes in enormous numbers. Few of them could get
food at hand and so, like people, animals, birds and fishes, they
migrated, going to the largest and nearest available food supply,
that at Gatun. This migration was not the only departure from
their ordinary routine that was forced upon them, as Mr. Le Prince
noted that they bit very freely in bright sunshine.

That the migrating mosquitoes were non-infected ones is
indicated by the fact that, notwithstanding the great numbers of them
entering houses, the malaria rate at Gatun for the eighteen weeks of
November, December, January and February, was actually lower than in
the corresponding weeks of the preceding year, the average weekly
admission rate being .30 and .32 percent, respectively.

I believe that what I have chosen to call the hypothesis
outlined above is in its entire form, new, yet the essential facts
that support it have been observed and reported by numerous workers,
and it is possible that these facts have even been grouped much as
I have grouped them, and the same general deductions drawn.

Mr. Le Prince in writing of the Gatun flights (Report
of the Department of Sanitation, Isthmian Canal Commission, January,
1913) said: “It was assumed that such a large number of adults as
would be produced every twenty-four hours at the production area
must of necessity spread out or travel a considerable distance in
order to get blood sufficient to satisfy them.”

Facts and deductions have been both interesting and
helpful to me and the hypothesis has in several instances served
as a working basis, enabling us to accomplish results with a
saving of money and to anticipate and prevent trouble.
